SENT.plain: We found substantial alterations in reactions catalyzed by calcium/phospholipid-dependent and calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinases during CNS ischemia which suggested that phenothiazines, drugs capable of inhibiting these reactions, might reduce neurologic damage
To test this hypothesis, we used chlorpromazine and trifluoperazine
Both drugs reduced neurologic function deficits relative to controls in a rabbit multiple cerebral embolism model and a rabbit spinal cord ischemia model
Chlorpromazine was effective despite reduction of blood pressure, and trifluoperazine did not alter blood pressure
These findings suggest that phenothiazines may be useful for preserving neurologic function when administered shortly after the onset of CNS ischemia
